p: Winged bean is consumed mainly in South Africa, Southern Asia, India and Malaysia [ 26]. All the parts of winged bean plants can be eaten, including the pods (raw or pickled, consumed largely in India [ 6]), flowers (used in salad and to color dishes [ 8]), leaves (prepared and eaten similar to spinach), roots (tubers. raw or cooked especially in Burma, Ghana, Papua New Guinea, Thailand and Indonesia) and seeds. The seeds are processed and consumed in diverse ways: Unripe seeds are eaten in soups [ 26, 27]; mature seeds can be eaten roasted, or dried and grounded to produce flour. Furthermore, oil can be extracted from the seeds and used in cooking or frying food.
